raw_text:
FAO warns on impact of subsidies
 
 Billions of farmers' livelihoods are at risk from falling commodity prices and protectionism, the UN's Food & Agriculture Organisation has warned.
 
 Trade barriers and subsidies "severely" distort the market, the FAO report on the "State of Agricultural Commodity Markets 2004" said. As a result, the 2.5 billion people in the developing world who rely on farming face food insecurity. The most endangered are those who live in the least-developed countries. The FAO report said that support for farmers in industrialised nations was equivalent to 30 times the amount provided as aid for agricultural development in poor countries.
 
 The FAO has urged the World Trade Organisation to swiftly conclude negotiations to liberalise trade, easing developing countries' access to the world market. It also criticised the high tariffs imposed by both developed and developing nations. It recommends that developing countries reduce their own tariffs to encourage trade and take advantage of market liberalisation.
 
 According to the organisation, subsidies and high tariffs have a strong impact on the trade of products such as cotton and rice. Global exports of these products are mainly in the hands of the European Union and the US, who - thanks to subsidies - sell them at very low prices. In fact, almost 30 wealthy nations spend more than $300bn (£158.8bn; 230.9bn euros) in agricultural subsidies. The market situation has divided developing nations in two groups, the FAO said. The first group have a reasonably diverse range of agricultural products while in the second group, agriculture lies largely in the hands of small-scale producers. For 43 developing countries, more than 20% of their export incomes come from the sale of just one product. These countries are mainly situated in Sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America and the Caribbean.
llama3.2:1b: The UN's Food & Agriculture Organisation (FAO) has warned that billions of farmers' livelihoods are at risk due to falling commodity prices and protectionism. The FAO report found that trade barriers and subsidies severely distort the market, leading to food insecurity for 2.5 billion people in developing countries, particularly those living in least-developed nations.
llama3.2:3b: The UN's Food & Agriculture Organisation warns that billions of farmers' livelihoods are at risk due to falling commodity prices and protectionism, which distort the market and lead to food insecurity for 2.5 billion people in developing countries, particularly those in least-developed countries. The FAO urges trade liberalisation through World Trade Organisation negotiations and recommends reducing tariffs to encourage trade and promote market liberalisation, as subsidies in industrialised nations are 30 times higher than aid provided for poor countries.
gemma2:2b: The Food & Agriculture Organisation warns that falling commodity prices and protectionist policies pose a significant threat to farmers' livelihoods worldwide, particularly those in developing countries. The report highlights the damaging effects of trade barriers and subsidies on market fairness and food security, emphasizing the unequal distribution of support for agricultural development between developed and developing nations. The FAO urges swift action from the World Trade Organisation to liberalize trade and reduce tariffs, advocating for greater access for developing countries in global markets.  The report further acknowledges the impact of high tariffs on products like cotton and rice, with major exporting powers benefitting at the expense of developing nations. Finally, it points out the vulnerability of smaller-scale producers in certain regions due to heavy reliance on a single agricultural product.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The FAO warns that subsidies and high tariffs on agricultural products like cotton and rice lead to food insecurity for millions of farmers worldwide. Developing nations' high tariff barriers hurt their own exports but also unfairly benefit developed countries. The FAO recommends reducing tariffs to encourage free trade and address issues related to agricultural subsidies.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The UN's Food & Agriculture Organisation warns that billions of farmers' livelihoods face risk due to falling commodity prices and protectionism, with developing world agriculture being particularly affected. High subsidies for industrialized nations and tariffs by both developed and developing countries distort global markets, threatening food insecurity in 2.5 billion people relying on farming worldwide. The FAO calls for the World Trade Organisation to conclude negotiations on liberalizing trade quickly, reducing high tariffs, and encouraging market access for developing countries.
qwen2.5:3b: FAO warns on impact of subsidies: Billions of farmers' livelihoods at risk due to falling commodity prices and protectionism. Trade barriers distort markets, particularly affecting developing nations, especially least-developed ones. The UN agency criticizes high tariffs in both industrialized and developing countries, urging for liberalization to benefit poorer nations. Subsidies influence trade in products like cotton and rice; wealthy nations spend over $300bn on agricultural subsidies. FAO divides developing countries into groups: first with diverse ag products, second where agriculture is controlled by small producers, leading to high dependency on exports of one primary commodity for income.
opencoder:1.5b: The FAO warns on the impact of subsidies on trade barriers that distort the market. As a result, billions of farmers worldwide face food insecurity. The most affected areas are those who live in the least-developed countries, while the support for industrialized nations is equivalent to 30 times the amount provided as aid for agricultural development in poor countries. According to the organisation, subsidies and high tariffs have a significant impact on the trade of products such as cotton and rice. Global exports exceed $300bn (£158.8bn; 230.9bn euros) from EU and US traders, while they are heavily subsidized by wealthy nations.
smollm:1.7b: The FAO warns on the impact of subsidies on the trade of commodities such as cotton and rice. The WTO has been urged to quickly conclude negotiations to liberalise trade, reducing tariffs for developing countries' exports. The high tariffs imposed by both developed and developing nations have a strong impact on the trade of these products. Developing countries are at risk of food insecurity due to the lack of access to markets. The FAO recommends that developing countries reduce their own tariffs to encourage trade and take advantage of market liberalisation.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about FAO's report on agricultural subsidies and trade. Let me read through it carefully.

The first sentence mentions that Billions of farmers' livelihoods are at risk from falling commodity prices and protectionism. That gives me a clear point: farmers' incomes could drop if prices go up or trade restrictions hit them hard.

Next, the FAO report talks about how subsidies and trade barriers "severely" distort the market. This distortion causes food insecurity, especially affecting those in least-developed countries because their livelihoods are more vulnerable.

The FAO also mentions that support for farmers in developed nations is way higher than what's provided for poor countries. They say farmers there get 30 times as much as aid to agriculture in developing areas. That makes the argument stronger that trade policies need changes.

Then, it suggests World Trade Organisation (WTO) should negotiate with each other on liberalizing trade. High tariffs and subsidies hurt global exporters who rely heavily on these products from EU and US, which sell them cheaply. The FAO recommends that developing countries cut their own tariffs to make more of their agricultural exports available worldwide.

Also, the report points out that subsidies and high tariffs affect cotton and rice export heavily, with many wealthy nations buying a lot in agricultural subsidies. They separate developing countries into two groups: those with diverse products and those controlled by small farmers. These low-income countries are mainly in Sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America, and the Caribbean.

I need to capture all these points concisely without getting too detailed. I'll mention the impact on farmers' livelihoods, the role of subsidies and trade barriers, the welfare of developing countries, and the recommendations from FAO and WTO.
</think>

The FAO warns that subsidies and high tariffs severely distort agricultural markets, leading to food insecurity in developing countries. It recommends World Trade Organisation negotiations for liberalization and calls for developed countries to reduce tariffs to allow agricultural exports to global markets. The report highlights issues with cotton and rice production, with most globally sourced products from EU and US heavily reliant on farmers. Low-income developing countries, such as those in Sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America, and the Caribbean, face particular challenges due to diverse agricultural product distribution and reliance on small-scale farmers.
tinyllama:1.1b: FAO warns on impact of subsidiaries on farm livelihoods, calling for quick liberalising trade negotiations and measures to encourage trade among developing countries. The organization says high tariffs and subsidies are severely distorting markets, threatening food insecurity and the livelihoods of millions of farmers worldwide. To address this, the FAO calls for the WTO to prioritize developing country access to market liberalization within the negotiations. The report also notes that trade barriers affecting the least-developed countries are equivalent to 30 times more aid given for agricultural development in poor nations.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The International Food & Agriculture Organisation (FAO) has warned on the impact of subsidies on farmers' livelihoods and pointed out that trade barriers are severely distorting the market. This report by FAO reveals that industrialized nations provide less aid to developing countries than they do to agriculture, leading to food insecurity among many people in the developing world. The report also suggests that high tariffs imposed by both developed and developing countries further hinder agricultural development in the latter group of countries. This, according to the FAO, can have detrimental effects on their trade in agricultural products.
phi:2.7b: The UN's Food & Agriculture Organization has warned that falling commodity prices and protectionism are putting billions of farmers' livelihoods at risk in developing nations due to trade barriers and subsidies which distort the market, severely affecting food security. The most vulnerable people live in least-developed countries and rely on farming. Developed nations provide 30 times more support than aid for agricultural development in poor countries. The FAO has urged the WTO to conclude negotiations to liberalize trade and reduce tariffs to encourage developing countries to take advantage of the market. The impact of subsidies and high tariffs is felt most strongly by the trade of products such as cotton and rice, with the EU and US selling them at very low prices due to subsidies. More than
orca-mini:3b: The FAO warns that subsidies and trade barriers severely distort the agricultural market, threatening the livelihoods of billions of farmers worldwide. Developing countries rely on trade to access markets, but high tariffs limit their ability to sell products such as cotton and rice. European Union and US subsidies allow them to sell at low prices.
hermes3:3b: FAO warns about subs & trade barriers damaging farmers' livelihoods in developing nations, leading to food insecurity; urges WTO to conclude trade liberalization negotiations.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The UN's Food & Agriculture Organisation (FAO) warns that billions of farmers' livelihoods are at risk due to falling commodity prices and protectionism. The FAO report on "State of Agricultural Commodity Markets 2004" states that trade barriers and subsidies severely distort the market, leading to food insecurity for 2.5 billion people in developing countries who rely on farming. The FAO urges the World Trade Organisation to conclude negotiations for liberalizing trade, easing access for developing countries to global markets. It also criticizes high tariffs imposed by both developed and developing nations and recommends that developing countries reduce their own tariffs to encourage trade. The report reveals that agricultural subsidies cost wealthy nations over $300 billion a year and have divided developing nations into two groups: those with diverse agricultural products and those relying on small-scale producers, primarily in Sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America, and the Caribbean.
stablelm2:1.6b: The Food & Agriculture Organisation (FAO) warns that billions of farmers' livelihoods are at risk due to falling commodity prices and protectionism. Falling commodity prices and support from industrialized nations disproportionately impact developing world farmers, particularly those in least-developed countries. The FAO suggests World Trade Organisation should quickly liberalize trade for better access to the global market by reducing their own tariffs. Agricultural subsidies and high tariffs have a significant impact on global agricultural exports, with wealthy nations spending significantly more on subsidies than poorer ones. Developing nations are divided into two groups: one has diverse agricultural products, while the other relies on small-scale agriculture. More than 50% of developing countries' export incomes come from just one product, which mainly impacts Sub- Saharan Africa, Latin America and Caribbean.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The FAO warns that billions of farmers worldwide face severe food insecurity due to falling commodity prices and protectionist policies. Trade barriers and subsidies distort markets, with industrialized nations providing 30 times more agricultural support than developing countries as aid. The report, "State of Agricultural Commodity Markets 2004," highlights that the most vulnerable are those in least-developed countries. Cotton and rice exports are heavily influenced by these subsidies, with wealthy nations spending over $300bn annually on agricultural support. The FAO urges the WTO to expeditiously negotiate trade liberalization, emphasizing that developing countries should reduce tariffs to capitalize on global market access. The report divides developing nations into two groups: those with diverse agricultural production and others where agriculture is dominated by small-scale producers, primarily in Sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America, and the Caribbean.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The UN's Food & Agriculture Organisation (FAO) warns that trade barriers and subsidies distort markets, threatening the livelihoods of 2.5 billion farmers in developing countries and increasing food insecurity, especially in the least-developed nations. The FAO highlights that subsidies in industrialised nations far exceed aid for agricultural development in poor countries. It urges the World Trade Organisation to accelerate trade liberalisation and criticises high tariffs imposed by both developed and developing nations. Subsidies and tariffs particularly impact cotton and rice trade, with the EU and US dominating exports by selling at low prices. Wealthy nations spend over $300bn annually on agricultural subsidies, creating disparities among developing countries. Some have diverse agricultural sectors, while others rely heavily on a single export product, particularly in Sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America, and the Caribbean.
reference: The FAO has urged the World Trade Organisation to swiftly conclude negotiations to liberalise trade, easing developing countries' access to the world market.The market situation has divided developing nations in two groups, the FAO said.Trade barriers and subsidies "severely" distort the market, the FAO report on the "State of Agricultural Commodity Markets 2004" said.It recommends that developing countries reduce their own tariffs to encourage trade and take advantage of market liberalisation.For 43 developing countries, more than 20% of their export incomes come from the sale of just one product.According to the organisation, subsidies and high tariffs have a strong impact on the trade of products such as cotton and rice.
